name: Alabama
citation: Code of Alabama § 36-12-40 et seq. (Alabama Open Records Act)
responseTime: A 'reasonable time.' If the record is in active use or storage, the custodian has up to 5 business days to respond.
feeStructure: Reasonable costs for copying, staff time, and any necessary technology costs. An estimate must be provided if costs exceed $50.
appeal_process: A person denied access can file a lawsuit in the circuit court of the county where the records are maintained.
exemptions_summary: Records where disclosure would be detrimental to the public interest, law enforcement investigative reports, and records made confidential by other state or federal laws.
request_format: No specific format required. Requests can be made orally or in writing, but written requests are recommended.

name: Alaska
citation: AS 40.25.110 et seq. (Alaska Public Records Act)
responseTime: 10 business days. Can be extended for an additional 10 business days under 'unusual circumstances.'
feeStructure: Actual costs of duplication. A fee may be charged for staff time required to produce the record if it exceeds five person-hours.
appeal_process: Denials can be appealed to the superior court.
exemptions_summary: Personnel records, medical records, records of attorney-client privilege, and certain law enforcement records. There is a public interest balancing test.

name: Arizona
citation: A.R.S. § 39-121 et seq. (Arizona Public Records Law)
responseTime: 'Promptly.' The courts have interpreted this to mean without unreasonable delay.
feeStructure: Non-commercial requests: reasonable fees for copying. Commercial requests: can also include costs for research, and a portion of the cost to maintain the records system.
appeal_process: A person can file a special action in the superior court to compel disclosure.
exemptions_summary: Records that are confidential by law, records where privacy interests outweigh the public's right to know, and records vital to state security.
request_format: No specific format required, but written requests are recommended.

name: Arkansas
citation: A.C.A. § 25-19-101 et seq. (Arkansas Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 3 business days. If the records are in active use or storage, the custodian must certify this and set a date and time when the records will be available.
feeStructure: Actual costs of reproduction, including supplies and mailing. No charge for staff time to locate or prepare records.
appeal_process: Appeals are made to the circuit court of the county where the records are located.
exemptions_summary: Income tax records, medical records, certain personnel records, and undisclosed law enforcement investigations.
request_format: No specific format required. Can be made in person, by phone, or in writing.

name: California
citation: Gov. Code § 7920.000 et seq. (California Public Records Act)
responseTime: 10 calendar days. Can be extended by 14 days under 'unusual circumstances' with written notice.
feeStructure: Direct costs of duplication. No charge for inspection or for the time it takes to search for, collect, or redact records.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in the superior court to enforce the law.
exemptions_summary: Numerous exemptions, including personnel files, pending litigation records, and preliminary drafts. A 'catch-all' exemption allows withholding if the public interest in nondisclosure clearly outweighs the public interest in disclosure.
request_format: No specific format, but written requests are strongly advised.

name: Colorado
citation: C.R.S. § 24-72-200.1 et seq. (Colorado Open Records Act - CORA)
responseTime: 3 business days. Can be extended by 7 business days if extenuating circumstances exist.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for copying. The first hour of research is free. After that, a reasonable fee can be charged.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in the district court.
exemptions_summary: Medical and personnel files, trade secrets, and records of sexual harassment complaints. A 'substantial injury to the public interest' balancing test applies to some records.

name: Connecticut
citation: C.G.S. § 1-200 et seq. (Connecticut Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 4 business days to acknowledge the request. Records must be provided 'promptly' thereafter.
feeStructure: Fees for copying are set by statute (e.g., $0.50 per page). No fee for inspection or electronic records sent by email.
appeal_process: Appeals are made to the state's Freedom of Information Commission.
exemptions_summary: Preliminary drafts, personnel or medical files, and certain law enforcement records if disclosure would be prejudicial to a pending case.
request_format: No specific format required, but written requests are standard.

name: Delaware
citation: 29 Del. C. § 10001 et seq. (Delaware Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 15 business days. The agency must provide a reason for any delay.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for copying and administrative costs (staff time for retrieval and redaction).
appeal_process: A petition can be filed with the Attorney General, who will issue an opinion. A person can also sue in the Superior Court.
exemptions_summary: Personnel files, investigatory files, trade secrets, and any record deemed confidential by other laws.

name: Florida
citation: F.S. Chapter 119 (Florida Public Records Act)
responseTime: 'Promptly and in good faith.' A 'reasonable time' is allowed to retrieve and redact records.
feeStructure: Actual cost of duplication. A 'special service charge' may apply if the request requires extensive use of technology or personnel.
appeal_process: File a civil action in the circuit court to compel compliance.
exemptions_summary: Florida has a very broad public records law, but there are over 1,000 specific statutory exemptions, including active criminal intelligence information and certain personal information.
request_format: No specific format required; can be oral or written.

name: Georgia
citation: O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. (Georgia Open Records Act)
responseTime: 3 business days. If some records cannot be produced within 3 days, the agency must provide a description and a timeline for when they will be available.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for copying (statutory limit of $0.10 per page) and administrative costs for search, retrieval, and redaction (prorated for the lowest-paid full-time employee who can do the work). First 15 minutes are free.
appeal_process: File a civil suit in the superior court. The Attorney General can also issue opinions.
exemptions_summary: Records related to pending investigations, real estate appraisals, and certain personal information. A balancing test exists for some records.
request_format: No specific format required, but written requests are recommended.

name: Hawaii
citation: HRS § 92F-1 et seq. (Uniform Information Practices Act)
responseTime: 10 business days. Can be extended for another 10 business days for good cause.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for search, review, and segregation of records, plus copying costs. Fees can be waived if the request is in the public interest.
appeal_process: Appeal to the Office of Information Practices (OIP), which can issue an advisory opinion. A lawsuit can also be filed in circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Government records that would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, and preliminary drafts or notes.

name: Idaho
citation: Idaho Code § 74-101 et seq. (Idaho Public Records Act)
responseTime: 3 business days. Can be extended to 10 business days with written notice.
feeStructure: No fee for the first 100 pages of paper records or the first two hours of labor. After that, reasonable fees for copying and labor can be charged.
appeal_process: File a petition with the magistrate court.
exemptions_summary: Personnel records, active law enforcement investigations, and records exempt by other statutes.

name: Illinois
citation: 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. (Illinois Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 5 business days. Can be extended for another 5 business days for specific reasons.
feeStructure: No fee for the first 50 pages of black and white, letter or legal sized copies. After that, fees are limited to the actual cost of reproduction.
appeal_process: Appeal to the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Attorney General's office, or file a lawsuit in circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Private information, law enforcement records that would interfere with proceedings, and preliminary drafts.

name: Indiana
citation: IC 5-14-3-1 et seq. (Indiana Access to Public Records Act)
responseTime: Agencies must respond within 24 hours for requests made in person or by telephone, and within 7 days for requests made by mail or fax.
feeStructure: Fees for copying are set by statute. Agencies may not charge for search or review.
appeal_process: File a complaint with the Public Access Counselor, or file a lawsuit in the circuit or superior court.
exemptions_summary: Investigatory records of law enforcement, personnel files of public employees, and confidential commercial information.
request_format: No specific format required, but must identify the records with 'reasonable particularity'.

name: Iowa
citation: Iowa Code Chapter 22 (Iowa Open Records Act)
responseTime: 'Without delay.' Generally interpreted as within 10 to 20 business days.
feeStructure: Reasonable expenses for the actual costs of providing the service, including copying and staff time if it exceeds 30 minutes.
appeal_process: File a complaint with the Iowa Public Information Board or file a lawsuit in district court.
exemptions_summary: Personal information in personnel records, student records, hospital records, and peace officers' investigative reports.

name: Kansas
citation: K.S.A. 45-215 et seq. (Kansas Open Records Act - KORA)
responseTime: 3 business days.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for staff time spent producing the records and for copying.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in district court.
exemptions_summary: Personnel records, medical treatment records, and records privileged under the rules of evidence.

name: Kentucky
citation: KRS 61.870 et seq. (Kentucky Open Records Act)
responseTime: 5 business days (excluding weekends and holidays).
feeStructure: Reasonable fee for copying, not to exceed the actual cost of reproduction. No charge for staff time.
appeal_process: Appeal to the Kentucky Attorney General. The AG's decision can then be appealed to the circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Records containing personal information where disclosure would be a clearly unwarranted invasion of privacy, and preliminary drafts and notes.
request_format: Written request required. Must be a resident of the Commonwealth.

name: Louisiana
citation: La. R.S. 44:1 et seq. (Louisiana Public Records Act)
responseTime: 5 business days.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for copying. An estimate must be provided in advance if fees are expected.
appeal_process: File a suit for a writ of mandamus in the district court.
exemptions_summary: Records pertaining to pending criminal litigation, and records containing software or security information.

name: Maine
citation: 1 M.R.S. § 401 et seq. (Maine Freedom of Access Act)
responseTime: 5 business days to acknowledge receipt and provide an estimated time and cost.
feeStructure: Direct costs of copying. After the first hour of staff time, can charge for search and retrieval at a rate of up to $25/hour.
appeal_process: File an appeal in Superior Court.
exemptions_summary: Records designated confidential by statute, and records that would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.

name: Maryland
citation: Md. Code, Gen. Prov. § 4-101 et seq. (Maryland Public Information Act - PIA)
responseTime: A 'reasonable period,' not to exceed 30 days. Must provide a definite time frame if more than 10 business days are needed.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for the actual costs of search, preparation, and reproduction. The first 2 hours of staff time are free.
appeal_process: Seek review by the Public Information Act Compliance Board or file a lawsuit in circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Personnel records, retirement records, student records, and investigatory records.

name: Massachusetts
citation: M.G.L. c. 66, § 10 (Massachusetts Public Records Law)
responseTime: 10 business days.
feeStructure: Fees for copying (5 cents per page for black and white) and for staff time to search and segregate records (capped at $25/hour after the first two hours for municipalities).
appeal_process: Appeal to the Supervisor of Public Records, who can order the release of records. Decisions can be appealed in superior court.
exemptions_summary: The 'privacy' exemption is common, protecting records where disclosure would be an unwarranted invasion of privacy. Also exempts policy-making documents.

name: Michigan
citation: MCL 15.231 et seq. (Michigan Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 5 business days. Can be extended for 10 additional business days.
feeStructure: Fees for labor costs (search, examination, redaction), copying, and mailing. A fee waiver is available for those in the public interest.
appeal_process: Appeal to the head of the public body. If denied again, a civil action can be filed in circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Information of a personal nature where public disclosure would be a clearly unwarranted invasion of an individual's privacy.

name: Minnesota
citation: Minn. Stat. Chapter 13 (Minnesota Government Data Practices Act)
responseTime: 'Reasonable amount of time.'
feeStructure: Actual costs of searching for and retrieving data, including the cost of employee time, and for making and transmitting copies.
appeal_process: Bring a civil action in district court.
exemptions_summary: Data classified as not public by statute, federal law, or a temporary classification. Includes personnel data and active investigative data.

name: Mississippi
citation: Miss. Code Ann. § 25-61-1 et seq. (Mississippi Public Records Act)
responseTime: 7 business days.
feeStructure: Fees reasonably calculated to reimburse the agency for the actual cost of searching, reviewing, duplicating, and mailing.
appeal_process: Petition the chancery court for a hearing.
exemptions_summary: Individual tax records, personnel files, and certain law enforcement records.

name: Missouri
citation: R.S.Mo. § 610.010 et seq. (Missouri Sunshine Law)
responseTime: No later than the end of the 3rd business day.
feeStructure: Fees for copying and for the time taken by clerical staff to locate and copy the records.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in the circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Individually identifiable personnel records, and records related to the leasing, purchase or sale of real estate until the transaction is complete.

name: Montana
citation: Montana Constitution, Art. II, Sec. 9; MCA § 2-6-1001 et seq.
responseTime: No specific time limit, but must be 'timely.'
feeStructure: A fee may be charged that is 'reasonably related to the cost of producing the record.'
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in district court.
exemptions_summary: The right to know is balanced against an individual's right to privacy. If the demand of individual privacy clearly exceeds the merits of public disclosure, the record is exempt.

name: Nebraska
citation: Neb. Rev. Stat. § 84-712 et seq. (Nebraska Public Records Statutes)
responseTime: 4 business days.
feeStructure: Actual cost of copying. A reasonable charge may be assessed for labor if it exceeds four hours.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in district court or a complaint with the Attorney General.
exemptions_summary: Personal records, law enforcement investigatory records, and trade secrets.

name: Nevada
citation: NRS Chapter 239 (Nevada Public Records Act)
responseTime: 5 business days.
feeStructure: Fees for copying. If a request requires more than 2 hours of staff time, a fee based on the employee's salary may be charged.
appeal_process: File a petition in district court.
exemptions_summary: Records declared confidential by law. A balancing test is used to weigh privacy or security interests against the public's right to know.

name: New Hampshire
citation: RSA Chapter 91-A (New Hampshire Right-to-Know Law)
responseTime: 5 business days.
feeStructure: Actual cost of reproduction. No charge for inspection.
appeal_process: File a petition in superior court or a complaint with the Right to Know Ombudsman.
exemptions_summary: Records whose disclosure would constitute an invasion of privacy, and records pertaining to internal personnel practices.

name: New Jersey
citation: N.J.S.A. 47:1A-1 et seq. (Open Public Records Act - OPRA)
responseTime: 7 business days.
feeStructure: Fees for copying are set by statute (e.g., $0.05 per page for letter size). A 'special service charge' may apply for extraordinary requests.
appeal_process: File a complaint with the Government Records Council (GRC) or file a lawsuit in Superior Court.
exemptions_summary: Inter-agency or intra-agency advisory material, information which would give an advantage to competitors or bidders, and personal identifying information.
request_format: Must be in writing and submitted on the agency's official OPRA request form.

name: New Mexico
citation: NMSA 1978, Chapter 14, Article 2 (Inspection of Public Records Act - IPRA)
responseTime: 3 business days to acknowledge and respond. Records must be produced within 15 calendar days.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for copying. No charge for inspection.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in district court or file a complaint with the Attorney General's office.
exemptions_summary: Matters of opinion in personnel files, letters of reference, and law enforcement records that reveal confidential sources or methods.

name: New York
citation: Public Officers Law, Article 6 (Freedom of Information Law - FOIL)
responseTime: 5 business days to acknowledge receipt. Must state approximate date when the request will be granted or denied.
feeStructure: Fees for copying (up to $0.25 per page) or the actual cost of reproduction. Two hours of staff time to prepare electronic records is free.
appeal_process: Appeal in writing to the head of the agency within 30 days. After that, an Article 78 proceeding can be brought in state supreme court.
exemptions_summary: Records that if disclosed would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, and inter-agency or intra-agency materials that are not statistical or factual tabulations.

name: North Carolina
citation: N.C. Gen. Stat. Chapter 132 (North Carolina Public Records Law)
responseTime: 'As promptly as possible.'
feeStructure: Actual cost of duplication. A special service charge can be applied for extensive use of information technology or clerical assistance.
appeal_process: File a civil action in superior court.
exemptions_summary: Criminal investigation records, confidential communications from attorneys, and sensitive public security information.

name: North Dakota
citation: N.D.C.C. § 44-04-18 (North Dakota Open Records Statute)
responseTime: 'Reasonable amount of time.'
feeStructure: A charge for the 'actual cost' of providing the copies.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in district court or request an opinion from the Attorney General.
exemptions_summary: Records that are specifically exempt by state or federal law. A balancing test is used for other records, weighing privacy against the public's right to know.

name: Ohio
citation: R.C. 149.43 (Ohio Public Records Act)
responseTime: 'Promptly.'
feeStructure: Actual cost of the copies.
appeal_process: File a mandamus action in the court of common pleas, court of appeals, or the supreme court.
exemptions_summary: Medical records, trial preparation records, and confidential law enforcement investigatory records.
request_format: No specific format required, but the request must be specific enough for the agency to identify the records.

name: Oklahoma
citation: 51 O.S. § 24A.1 et seq. (Oklahoma Open Records Act)
responseTime: 'Prompt, reasonable access.'
feeStructure: Fees for copying and for recovering the direct cost of record search and copying if the request is for a commercial purpose or would cause excessive disruption.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in district court.
exemptions_summary: Personnel records related to internal discipline, and law enforcement records if it would compromise an ongoing investigation.

name: Oregon
citation: ORS 192.311 to 192.478 (Oregon Public Records Law)
responseTime: 5 business days to acknowledge receipt. Must complete the response as soon as practicable and without unreasonable delay.
feeStructure: Fees reasonably calculated to reimburse the agency for its actual cost in making records available.
appeal_process: Petition the District Attorney or the Attorney General for review. Their order can be appealed in circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Records of a personal nature if disclosure would be an unreasonable invasion of privacy, and investigatory information compiled for criminal law purposes.

name: Pennsylvania
citation: 65 P.S. § 67.101 et seq. (Pennsylvania Right-to-Know Law)
responseTime: 5 business days.
feeStructure: Fees for copying, postage, and other specific costs are set by the Office of Open Records.
appeal_process: Appeal to the Pennsylvania Office of Open Records within 15 business days of a denial.
exemptions_summary: Records that would reveal the institution's deliberative process, and records that would threaten public safety or a building's physical security.
request_format: Must be in writing and submitted to the agency's Open Records Officer.

name: Rhode Island
citation: R.I. Gen. Laws § 38-2-1 et seq. (Access to Public Records Act - APRA)
responseTime: 10 business days. Can be extended for 20 additional business days for good cause.
feeStructure: First hour of search and retrieval is free. After that, up to $15/hour. Copying fees are limited to 15 cents per page.
appeal_process: File a complaint with the chief administrative officer of the public body, then to the Department of Attorney General, or file a suit in superior court.
exemptions_summary: Trade secrets, collective bargaining records, and records that would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.

name: South Carolina
citation: S.C. Code § 30-4-10 et seq. (South Carolina Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 10 business days for records less than 24 months old; 20 business days for older records.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for the search, retrieval, and redaction of records. A fee schedule must be publicly available.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in the circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Records that would be an unreasonable invasion of personal privacy, and law enforcement records that would harm an ongoing investigation.

name: South Dakota
citation: SDCL Chapter 1-27 (South Dakota Open Records Law)
responseTime: 'Promptly.' If a delay is necessary, the custodian must provide a written explanation within 10 business days.
feeStructure: Fees for copying and any necessary mailing costs. Fees may not exceed the actual cost of reproduction.
appeal_process: File a lawsuit in circuit court or request assistance from the Open Meetings Commission.
exemptions_summary: Personnel information other than date of employment and salary, and student records.

name: Tennessee
citation: T.C.A. § 10-7-503 et seq. (Tennessee Public Records Act)
responseTime: 7 business days.
feeStructure: A schedule of reasonable charges must be established by the Office of Open Records Counsel. Labor is not charged for inspection.
appeal_process: File a petition in chancery or circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Medical records of patients in state institutions, and certain law enforcement investigation records.
request_format: Written request required for copies. Must be a citizen of Tennessee.

name: Texas
citation: Tex. Gov't Code Chapter 552 (Texas Public Information Act)
responseTime: 'Promptly,' which the law presumes is within 10 business days. If more time is needed, the agency must notify the requester and set a date.
feeStructure: Charges for copying and labor are set by the Attorney General's office.
appeal_process: File a complaint with the Attorney General's Open Records Division or file a lawsuit for a writ of mandamus.
exemptions_summary: Information considered confidential by law (constitutional, statutory, or judicial decision), and information related to pending litigation.

name: Utah
citation: Utah Code § 63G-2-101 et seq. (Government Records Access and Management Act - GRAMA)
responseTime: 10 business days. Can be expedited to 5 business days for a fee.
feeStructure: Reasonable fees for the actual cost of copying and compiling the records.
appeal_process: Appeal to the chief executive of the governmental entity, then to the State Records Committee or district court.
exemptions_summary: Records that are private, controlled, or protected under the statute. Uses a balancing test to weigh privacy interests against the public interest in access.

name: Vermont
citation: 1 V.S.A. § 315 et seq. (Vermont Public Records Act)
responseTime: 3 business days. Can be extended up to 10 business days.
feeStructure: Actual cost of copying. Staff time may be charged for producing a record in a non-standard format.
appeal_process: Appeal to the head of the agency. If denied, a lawsuit can be filed in superior court.
exemptions_summary: Records dealing with the detection and investigation of crime, and personal documents relating to an individual.

name: Virginia
citation: Va. Code § 2.2-3700 et seq. (Virginia Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 5 business days. Can be extended for 7 additional business days.
feeStructure: Reasonable charges for the actual costs incurred in accessing, duplicating, supplying, or searching for the requested records.
appeal_process: File a petition for mandamus or injunction in the general district or circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Personnel records, written advice of legal counsel, and records relating to the negotiation and award of a contract prior to a contract being awarded.
request_format: No specific format required. Must be a citizen of the Commonwealth or a media representative.

name: Washington
citation: RCW 42.56 (Washington Public Records Act)
responseTime: 5 business days to respond by either providing the record, denying the request, or providing a reasonable estimate of the time needed.
feeStructure: A fee of 15 cents per page for photocopies, or the actual cost of producing electronic copies. No fee for inspection.
appeal_process: Seek judicial review in the superior court of the county where the record is maintained.
exemptions_summary: Personal information of individuals if disclosure would violate their right to privacy, and specific intelligence information for law enforcement.

name: West Virginia
citation: W. Va. Code § 29B-1-1 et seq. (West Virginia Freedom of Information Act)
responseTime: 5 business days.
feeStructure: A fee schedule reasonably related to the actual cost of reproduction.
appeal_process: File for injunctive or declaratory relief in the circuit court.
exemptions_summary: Trade secrets, information of a personal nature that would be an unreasonable invasion of privacy, and certain law enforcement records.

name: Wisconsin
citation: Wis. Stat. §§ 19.31-19.39 (Wisconsin Open Records Law)
responseTime: 'As soon as practicable and without delay.'
feeStructure: Actual, necessary, and direct cost of reproduction. Location costs may be imposed if they exceed $50.
appeal_process: Bring an action for mandamus in circuit court or request an opinion from the Attorney General.
exemptions_summary: Uses a balancing test. Access is denied only if the harm to the public interest from disclosure outweighs the strong public interest in openness.

name: Wyoming
citation: Wyo. Stat. § 16-4-201 et seq. (Wyoming Public Records Act)
responseTime: 'Reasonable time.' The custodian must provide the records 'as soon as is practical.'
feeStructure: Reasonable fee for making copies and for the cost of programming and computer services needed to produce the record.
appeal_process: File a petition in district court.
exemptions_summary: Investigatory records, personnel files, and records that would result in a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.
